A projection of this equation along the direction perpendicular to the arm gives a more simple equation:

Part 2: solver validation at small angles

children.label: Part 2: solver validation at small angles

children.value: In this first part, we want to validate the operation of the numerical solvers by comparing their results to a known exact solution. To do so, we will focus on the case of the simple pendulum oscillating at small angles. In this case, the sine can be approximated by

children.html: sin⁡θ≈θ\sin \theta \approx \thetasinθ≈θ

children.value: and the equation of the pendulum can be reduced to that of a harmonic oscillator. The exact solution is then:

children.html: x(t)=θ0cos⁡(ω0t)x(t) = \theta_0 \cos(\omega_0 t)x(t)=θ0​cos(ω0​t)

children.value: Solve the problem with Euler, RK4 and ODEint integrators and compare the results with the closed form solution. First assume that the pendulum is released with no speed (

children.value: . The time discretization will be as follows:

children.html: ta=0t_a = 0ta​=0

children.value:
def Euler(func, X0, t):
    """
    Euler integrator.
    """
    dt = t[1] - t[0]
    nt = len(t)
    X = np.zeros([nt, len(X0)])
    X[0] = X0
    for i in range(nt - 1):
        X[i + 1] = X[i] + func(X[i], t[i]) * dt
    return X


def RK4(func, X0, t):
    """
    Runge and Kutta 4 integrator.
    """
    dt = t[1] - t[0]
    nt = len(t)
    X = np.zeros([nt, len(X0)])
    X[0] = X0
    for i in range(nt - 1):
        k1 = func(X[i], t[i])
        k2 = func(X[i] + dt / 2.0 * k1, t[i] + dt / 2.0)
        k3 = func(X[i] + dt / 2.0 * k2, t[i] + dt / 2.0)
        k4 = func(X[i] + dt * k3, t[i] + dt)
        X[i + 1] = X[i] + dt / 6.0 * (k1 + 2.0 * k2 + 2.0 * k3 + k4)
    return X


# ODEint is preloaded.
